Install Open Broadcaster Software

  1. In your web browser, navigate to obsproject.com and select your computer's operating system from the home page. Download should begin immediately. Troubleshooting: If download doesn't begin, navigate to obsproject.com/download, select your operating sysyem, and click "Download Installer."
  2. Go to your computer's "Downloads" folder and open the downloaded obs-mac-24.0.6.dmg file.
  3. Drag the application to your "Applications" folder as prompted.

Install Soundflower

  1. Download: soundflower_2.0b2.zip
  2. Go to your computer's "Downloads" folder and open the downloaded .zip file. This will unzip the folder. Open the newly created folder and run the Soundflower.pkg file.
  3. The installer will tell you that it failed. This is completely normal.
  4. Open the computer's System Preferences and go to the “Security & Privacy” settings.
  5. Click on the “Allow” button next to “MATT INGALS”.
  6. Run the installer again. This time it will run through without any problems.
  7. Troubleshooting: Visit Flux Forge Blog

Audio Settings

  1. Open the computer's System Preferences and go to the "Sound" settings.
  2. Click the tab that says "output" and make sure your "headphones" are selected.
  3. With your class music playing, turn up the volume to the loudest point you will want during class. You will only be able to turn it down after this point; not up.
  4. Now select "Soundflower (2ch)" as the output. You will no longer hear the music. This is normal.
  5. Turn the "Output volume" all the way up.
  6. Click the tab that says "Input" and make sure that "External microphone" is selected.
  7. Talk and adjust the "Input volume" until you see signal on 80% of the bars.
  8. Now select "Soundflower (2ch)" as your input and turn the "Input volume" all the way up.

Open Broadcaster Software

  1. Open OBS from the "Applications" folder.
  2. Follow the setup prompts.
  3. In the main window, Click on the gear icon below "Desktop Audio", click "Properties", select "Soundflower (2ch)" from the Device drop down menu. Click "OK".
  4. Click on the same gear icon, click "Advanced Audio Properties"
  5. On the top row labeled "Desktop Audio" go to the "Audio Monitoring" column and select "Monitor and Output" from the drop down menu. You should hear your music again.
  6. Now you can adjust the volume of your music with the computer's volume controls but note that this does affect the level of music going to the stream.
  7. Close the Advanced Audio Properties window.
  8. In the main window, Click on the gear icon below "Mic/Aux", click "Properties", select "Built-in Microphone" from the Device drop down menu. Click "OK".
  9. Talk, clap, snap or make some kind of distinct sound to make sure you can see level on the audio meter.
